rows.title: What is Safeguarding?

title.eng: What is Safeguarding?

introduction.eng:
It is important to know the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:

1ï¸âƒ£ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**

â— **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a childâ€™s security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)

â— **Violence** against children is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,
Article 19)

â— **Child exploitation** refers to using the child for economical or sexual benefit, for gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the child. (Save the Children definition)

2ï¸âƒ£ **Know your organisationâ€™s child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**

ğŸ“– All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a parent or child discloses abuse. 

ğŸ“ You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a parent or child reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the child), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities). 

ğŸ”‘ It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.

3ï¸âƒ£ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**

ğŸŒ·Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when abuse occurred. 

ğŸ‘‚You should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgement or any further harm.

rows.title: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

title.eng: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**During disclosure:**

ğŸ’š Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.

ğŸ‘‚ Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.

â— Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.

ğŸ’™ Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.

ğŸŒ· Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.

rows.title: What can I do **after** a participant discloses abuse, neglect or exploitation?

introduction.eng:

âŒ Avoid engaging with alleged abuser â€“ that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.

rows.title: Week 1: Introductions

title.eng: Week 1: Introductions

introduction.eng: This first session offers a chance for members to introduce themselves to the group.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒ Hello and thanks for joining us in this chat. I hope you're all making progress in ParentText. Please PM me if you need help! 

Today we are introducing ourselves! â­ Please share your name and your goal for the programme. As an example: 

My name is ____ and I want to learn more about how to help my child go to bed by 8 every night.â°ğŸŒ™ 

Feel free to add your own to the chat using text or audio message. ğŸ“±

message_text_2.eng:
Thanks so much for sharing! To make this a safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules:
 
âœ… What is said in the group stays in the group. You need to know that this group is private.
âœ… Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
âœ… Share only what you feel comfortable sharing.
âœ… Feel free to ask questions!
âœ… Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 
âœ… I am only here as an observer. I will not respond to questions about your parenting habits in this group or personally. However, if there is a message that will benefit the entire group, then I will share a general message here.

Are there any other ground rules that you would like to add?

message_title_3.eng: Thank you for sharing! If you don't feel like you can agree to these rules, please send me a message and I can remove you from the group.

rows.title: Week 2: One-on-One Time

title.eng: Week 2: One-on-One Time

introduction.eng:
This session allows parents to discuss the importance of one-on-one time with their child. Remember, the key building blocks for One-on-One time are Day, Play, and Stay:

**DAY** Try to do it every day
Spend 5 minutes (or more!) One-on-One time with your child each day.

**PLAY** Let them choose the activity
Tell your child that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy this time with you!

**STAY** Focus on your child 
Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your child or teen. Nod or say â€œI seeâ€ to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

The goal is for parents to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time with their child each day.

message_text_1.eng:
Hi parents! ğŸ˜ƒ We are starting off this week with our first parenting tip! We are learning about spending one-on-one time with our children. âœ¨

Spending quality time with your children makes them feel secure and loved. Here are 3 things to try when you are spending One-on-One time with your children:

1ï¸âƒ£ **DAY**: Try to spend One-on-One time with your children every day.

2ï¸âƒ£ **PLAY**: Let them choose the activity.

3ï¸âƒ£ **STAY**: Stay totally focused on your child. Show them you are paying attention by looking and responding to them.

message_text_2.eng:
Why do you think spending One-on-One Time with your children could be helpful? ğŸ’¡

Tell us here using text or audio message. ğŸ“ You can respond to each otherâ€™s messages and give each other ideas too! ğŸ“±

message_text_3.eng:
Thanks for sharing so many wonderful responses! ğŸ‰ 

Your child will be really happy if you get to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time each day. ğŸ˜ƒ

rows.title: Week 3: Sharing Emotions

title.eng: Week 3: Sharing Emotions

introduction.eng:
ğŸˆ The primary objectives for this week are parents learning and practising how to talk about their own feelings and their childrenâ€™s feelings. ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜’ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜£ 

ğŸ¨ The key building blocks for Talking about Emotions are OPEN, SHARE, LEARN, TALK, NOTICE, CARE.

section_text_1.eng:
Be open to your childâ€™s emotions. Notice ğŸ‘€  and listen ğŸ‘‚ to children when they share how they are feeling.

Share your feelings. This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to our children. ğŸ˜£ But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress. ğŸ”„

section_text_2.eng:
Learn about the different emotions
The 6 basic emotions are: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜’ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜£ It is normal for everyone to experience feelings in different ways.

section_text_3.eng: Talk about emotions ğŸ”‘ It takes some practice to learn how to identify your own emotions and communicate them with others. Accept that your feelings are okay, even if they are negative. ğŸŒ±

section_text_4.eng: Notice your childâ€™s emotions. ğŸ’™ This is also very hard! Stress or conflict makes us focus on ourselves first, which is not wrong. ğŸŒ· It is important to take care of ourselves too.  But our children and teens need our support too. ğŸ’› When you notice their emotions, they will appreciate your efforts.

section_text_5.eng: â­ Ask your children how they feel. ğŸ§¸ Use physical or verbal support to comfort them.  ğŸ‘‚ Listen to them and tell them you are there for them.

message_text_1.eng:
Hi again parents! We hope your week went well. â­ Todayâ€™s parent tip is about sharing your emotions and talking about your childrenâ€™s feelings. ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜’ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜£

6ï¸âƒ£ Here are six tips on how to share your own emotions with your children and recognising their feelings in a healthy way:

1ï¸âƒ£ **OPEN** 
Notice ğŸ‘€  and listen ğŸ‘‚ to Your Child when they share how they are feeling.

2ï¸âƒ£ **SHARE** 
ğŸŒ· This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to our children. ğŸ˜£ But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress. ğŸ”„

3ï¸âƒ£ **LEARN** about the different emotions
The 6 basic emotions are: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜’ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜£ It is normal for everyone to experience feelings in different ways.

4ï¸âƒ£ **TALK** about emotions
ğŸ”‘ It takes some practice to learn how to identify your own emotions and communicate them with others. Accept that your feelings are okay, even if they are negative. ğŸŒ±

5ï¸âƒ£ **NOTICE** 
ğŸ’™ This is also very hard! Stress or conflict makes us focus on ourselves first, which is not wrong. ğŸŒ· It is important to take care of ourselves too.  But our children and teens need our support too. ğŸ’› When you notice their emotions, they will appreciate your efforts. 

6ï¸âƒ£ **CARE** 
â­ Ask your children how they feel. ğŸ§¸ Use physical or verbal support to comfort them.  ğŸ‘‚ Listen to them and tell them you are there for them.

message_text_2.eng: Why do you think itâ€™s helpful for your child to share their emotions?

message_text_3.eng:
Thanks for sharing your ideas! âœ¨

Try talking to your children about their emotions during One-on-One Time and at other times during the week. ğŸ‘‚ğŸ’š

Try to become more aware of your own emotions as you go about your day, too! ğŸ‘€ğŸŒ·

ğŸ”‘ It takes some practice to learn how to identify your own emotions and communicate them with others. Accept that your feelings are okay, even if they are negative. ğŸŒ±

5ï¸âƒ£ **NOTICE** 
ğŸ’™ This is also very hard! Stress or conflict makes us focus on ourselves first, which is not wrong. ğŸŒ· It is important to take care of ourselves too.  But our children and teens need our support too. ğŸ’› When you notice their emotions, they will appreciate your efforts. 

6ï¸âƒ£ **CARE** 
â­ Ask your children how they feel. ğŸ§¸ Use physical or verbal support to comfort them.  ğŸ‘‚ Listen to them and tell them you are there for them.

rows.title: Week 4: Childrenâ€™s Learning

title.eng: Week 4: Childrenâ€™s Learning

introduction.eng:
This week will focus on how parents can help their child to learn. 
The most important and easy ways parents can help their young child learn are to TALK, READ, and PLAY. Learn more below.

sections_title.eng: How Parents Help Their Children Learn

section_text_1.eng: Parents should talk with their child: describe things they both do, follow their childâ€™s interest, and ask lots of questions! When their child answers, they should explore what they say, and build on it by adding more information.

section_text_2.eng:
Parents should read with their child: talk about pictures, share books, and notice letters and words everywhere. 

ğŸ“– Itâ€™s great if they can read a childrenâ€™s book with their child, but if they canâ€™t then looking at pictures and words in old magazines and newspapers is good too! ğŸˆğŸ§¸ğŸŒ· Itâ€™s even a good idea to point at signs and labels and show children the letters that make the words! 

â¡ï¸ They should follow the childâ€™s interest again, point at things and say what they are, and ask lots of questions! ğŸ‘€

section_text_3.eng:
Parents should play with numbers, shapes, and categories with their child. Play counting games, point out numbers and shapes to their child, and have fun with sorting things into groups. 

â—Parents can do these learning activities in their normal routine if they donâ€™t have much time. Activities like sorting clothes and cooking can become fun learning activities!

message_text_1.eng:
Hello parents! Learning can start at a young age, and there are some ways you can help!

ğŸ˜ƒ Go slowly, and keep it light and fun! 

â— If your child is learning very difficult things, they may be discouraged from learning more. 

1ï¸âƒ£ **TALK** with your child. Describe things that you and your child are doing. Follow your childâ€™s interest and ask lots of questions. ğŸ‘€ When your child answers, explore what they say and build on it with more information! ğŸ’¡

2ï¸âƒ£ **READ** with your child. ğŸ“– Itâ€™s great if you can read a childrenâ€™s book with your child, but looking at pictures in magazines and old newspapers is good too! ğŸˆğŸ§¸ğŸŒ· Point out letters wherever you see them! If your child is ready, they can start writing some letters, like the first letter of their name!

3ï¸âƒ£ **PLAY** with numbers, shapes, and categories. Learning should be fun! Play some counting and sorting games with your child - you can use objects around you, like socks or even stones and sticks! ğŸ”µ ğŸ”´ ğŸ”¶ ğŸ”· Point out numbers to your child wherever you see them! 

â—You can do these activities in your normal routine if you donâ€™t have much time. Activities like sorting clothes and cooking can become fun learning activities!

message_text_2.eng: Why do you think itâ€™s important to make learning fun and playful for your child? ğŸ’¡

message_text_3.eng:
Thanks for sharing your ideas!

Remember that children learn best when they are enjoying themselves. Playing together is a great opportunity for learning!

Show an interest in what your child is doing in the next few days and talk with them about it. ğŸ’š

Involve your child in the things that you are doing - and make it fun. For example, help your child count ingredients while you are cooking! ğŸ…

Try doing some reading activities or looking at pictures together. Itâ€™s great if you can make a routine of looking at books or pictures together - like some time in the evening â°

rows.title: Week 5: Healthy Eating

title.eng: Week 5: Healthy Eating

introduction.eng: Parents will focus on their child's healthy eating habits this week. This session will allow parents to discuss the importance of training children to practise healthy eating habits from a young age.

section_text_1.eng:
The three tips that parents can follow to support their child's healthy eating habits are:  

1ï¸âƒ£ **FIND A HEALTHY BALANCE**:  Let the child enjoy a variety of food based on the recommended daily intakes.

2ï¸âƒ£ **MANAGE EMOTIONS**: Redirect or ignore the child's demanding behaviour for unhealthy food.

3ï¸âƒ£ **KEEP IT CLEAN**: Wash your hands and fresh food items before cooking. Maintain freshness of food by storing them in the fridge.

section_text_2.eng:
This week you will also ask the group to choose two group moderators to keep the WhatsApp Support Group ongoing. 

The WhatsApp groups are designed to support parent engagement in the ParentText chatbot. 

Select the 2 parents who receive the most votes to lead the group.

message_text_1.eng:
Hello parents! ğŸŒ· It's about encouraging your children to eat healthy and safe food. ğŸš ğŸ’›

3ï¸âƒ£ The following three tips will help your children to enjoy clean and tasty food. These tips will also help you to manage any food-related tantrums from your children.

1ï¸âƒ£ **FIND A HEALTHY BALANCE**: It is alright to let your children enjoy a variety of food based on the recommended daily intakes.

2ï¸âƒ£ **MANAGE EMOTIONS**: When your children are demanding unhealthy food, you can redirect or ignore their behaviour.

3ï¸âƒ£ **KEEP IT CLEAN**: Remember to wash your hands and fresh food items before cooking. Take advantage of the fridge to maintain freshness of cooked food.

rows.title: Week 6: Final Chat Session

title.eng: Week 6: Final Chat Session

introduction.eng:
This week, you will share the names of the two group moderators to keep the WhatsApp Support Group ongoing, and handover the WhatsApp group to them. 

Remember, the WhatsApp groups are designed to support parent engagement in the ParentText chatbot. 
Select the two parents who received the most votes to lead the group. Enter the name of the parents after sharing the Group Message 1. 
It is important that you share the guidelines with selected group moderators and conduct a brief group WhatsApp call with both to answer any further questions they may have. After this brief call, you can hand over the group admin responsibilities to the group moderators.
At the end of the programme, you will transfer group ownership to the two moderators and exit the WhatsApp group. If no group moderators are identified, the original group should be closed.
